retest this please
Please reopen the PR or push an empty commit to trigger travis.

@jerryshao it run into this weird
```
[ERROR] error: error reading /home/travis/.m2/repository/commons-io/commons-io/2.4/commons-io-2.4.jar; error in opening zip file
[ERROR] 1 error
```
error again

By impersonation, do you mean that the Spark application Livy spawns (to run queries) is run as the user connecting to the Thrift server? I have a user kinit'd, let's say using principal testuser, who connects via beeline to the Thrift server; and the Spark application for the session runs as testuser. If this is what you mean, then impersonation is working.

I tested my patch using both binary and http mode. In binary mode, everything works as I expect. In http mode, everything still works, except that on the server side, there are many exceptions logged, due to
`Caused by: org.apache.hive.service.auth.HttpAuthenticationException: Authorization header received from the client is empty.
`
but they do not cause any failure. I believe these exceptions are an unrelated issue.

Without my patch, I am able to connect when using http mode (the same slew of exceptions about the empty authorization header also occur in the server log), but I am unable to connect when using binary mode, due to the error as described in JIRA.
Thus I fail to see why you say the existing behavior is correct.

This patch fixes the binary mode case, and as far as I can tell, does not break existing behavior.
If you think the existing behavior is correct, and that the failure I experience in binary mode is due to some kind of misconfiguration or user error, I'd very much appreciate knowing what configuration I need to correct or what I am missing in my beeline command. Please comment in JIRA with the information.
@yiheng Could you please review the new commit again? All checks have passed now.
Yes, it is super weird, I've never met this issue before, can you reproduce it locally?

No issues locally.
I'm not familiar with this build process, but it looks like there is some issue with `/home/travis/.m2/repository/commons-io/commons-io/2.4/commons-io-2.4.jar` in maven cache. Can you please delete that file?

I think the point is that in your JIRA you are using HTTP/... as principal when you connect to beeline. You should use the principal Livy server is using instead.

> I have a user kinit'd, let's say using principal testuser, who connects via beeline to the Thrift server; and the Spark application for the session runs as testuser. If this is what you mean, then impersonation is working.

yes, that is impersonation. Yes, it may not be a problem because in your case you're forcing to use the HTTP principal only for the authentication, but the livy one is used everywhere else, the problem in this case would be token renewal most likely...you are creating the UGI once and never renewing it, so it would not work after 1 week or even 1 day probably.

The reason I use the HTTP principal in my beeline connection is because that is the principal configured in livy.server.auth.kerberos.principal. If I use the livy principal in my beeline connection, the connection still fails with the "GSS initiate failed" error. (This is with the existing code, before I made any changes.)
I understand that my patch may not be correct (not dealing with token renewal), but there is a real issue here.
Concerning renewal, can you point me to where/how the current code takes care of token renewal?

> If I use the livy principal in my beeline connection, the connection still fails with the "GSS initiate failed" error. (This is with the existing code, before I made any changes.)

this is weird. I'd need to investigate this but I don't have a cluster so I am not sure how to help you.

> Concerning renewal, can you point me to where/how the current code takes care of token renewal?

Please check the `LivyServer` class.
I guess we cannot delete the maven cache, it is the behavior of Travis. I was thinking it might not be the environment issue, would you please take a deep look?
Let's wait this until the whole HA design and plan settles down.

> @yiheng Could you please review the new commit again? All checks have passed now.

I only have one comment. Others look good to me.

Livy user in my company is asking for Rest API Load Balance functionality these days. So I go throught #189 and #212 and then I realize service discovery for Rest is quite different with Thrift. The main difference is thrift is a long connection while rest is not. When thrift connect is break, the session is shutdown but rest session is not. And another difference is thrift's client are exsiting hive client while rest have many different clients.  
These differences make thrift service discovery much easier than rest, so maybe we should consider them seperately.

I think this is a maven cache issue on that particular machine. Only 1 job is failing with this build issue, the `Spark 2.2 Unit Tests`. Other jobs, including the `Spark 2.2 ITs` are ok and they have no issue with `scala-maven-plugin:3.2.2:compile (scala-compile-first) @ livy-api` phase.

> Beeline from Hive 2.2 has in-place progress bar hive.server2.in.place.progress
>
>https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/Hive/Configuration+Properties#ConfigurationProperties-hive.server2.in.place.progress
>
>(I think it works only with tez - would be nice if this would work with Livy too )

Would be better to support this if it is not a big effort.
Do we need to change client-http module also to support BASIC authentication?

> Do we need to change client-http module also to support BASIC authentication?

Open a new JIRA for that？

> > Beeline from Hive 2.2 has in-place progress bar hive.server2.in.place.progress
> > https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/Hive/Configuration+Properties#ConfigurationProperties-hive.server2.in.place.progress
> > (I think it works only with tez - would be nice if this would work with Livy too )
> 
> Would be better to support this if it is not a big effort.

After reading hive related code, this needs write some new classes to implement this feature, which might cause this PR large, if you don not mind, I'd love to open a new PR to support this.
Sure, I'm fine with it.

I agree they are different and they may also lead to separate solutions, but I'd prefer to work on a full proposal which covers both cases. You may want to create a design doc and start a discussion maybe, proposing the solution you consider more appropriate. Once the design doc is approved I am happy to go ahead with this.
LGTM as well. Thanks, merging to master.

thanks for the patch @peter-toth. I remember there were issues with the thrifserver part due to dependencies on hive which created issues with jetty versions different to the one used earlier. Have you checked that thriftserver works in http mode too with this patch?
cc @ajbozarth
@jahstreet I noticed this is still WIP and it has been so for a long. Are you still working on this?
Thanks for letting me know about that issue. I will check it with the updated Jetty version.

Is there a reason you added 8 new bootstrap files? When downloading bootstrap it allows you to pick and choose which files you need. When we created the UI we made sure to only include the bootstrap files we use in order to minimize the size of the UI static files directory. So if you only included them because they came with the default download you should instead only update the ones we already had. 

The rest of the changes LGTM
Thanks @ajbozarth for the review. I will remove the unused files then.
close this PR as there is better solution.

The bootstrap instance in `docs` looked like a 'full' bootstrap (both normal and minified js were there, included bootstrap-theme files without any reference, ...) that's why I added the full 3.4.1 first.

Now I modified my PR to update necessary new files only and also removed some unused old ones.

Ah, I see what you mean. The docs should actually be treated as separate from the rest of the Livy server files then. They are designed to be built in conjunction with the livy website and are based on an apache template ( https://github.com/apache/apache-website-template ). I would suggest either leaving the docs alone or updating them in a separate PR tied with a PR on the livy website repo ( https://github.com/apache/incubator-livy-website ) with a matching update. 

What exactly is the CVE reasoning behind the update to begin with? If its worth updating apache website code it should be raised across all the projects which utilize the website template. If it's not then just updating our server version should be fine.

A clarification on the doc relation to the website. The themes dir your updating was copied into the main repo from the website repo so users could build and see local copies of the docs without cloning the website repo. Whereas on a release we copy a build on the docs into the website repo, but that copy would then reference the themes dir in the website repo. Therefore we need to keep those dirs completely in sync.

Thanks @ajbozarth for the clarification, I've reverted all `docs` related changes.
Blackduck reported  CVE-2019-11358 regarding current JQuery and CVE-2018-14040, CVE-2018-20676, CVE-2016-10735, CVE-2019-8331, CVE-2018-14042 regarding current Bootstrap.

> GSS initiate failed

can you share full exception stack? perhaps it's some sort of kerberos client misconfiguration on 
livy client server, or livy server side.. hard to tell without knowing details.

I updated the JIRA to explain that the problem was due to using an internal version of Livy that had some changes incompatible with the Thrift server; the changes caused the UGI for the livy principal to be obtained from ticket cache instead of keytab; this is what caused the "GSS initiate failed" error when trying to connect from beeline.
Closing this PR.

Hi @mgaido91 @jerryshao , I create a JIRA https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LIVY-698 to propose a cluster solution, could you please take a look. 
Thanks a lot!

@jerryshao And sorry for my late reply! I believe this PR should resolve issues with running the Livy server on Windows (at least with my tests). However it does not resolve *developing* on windows. LIVY-611 refers specifically to integration/unit tests. For example in the MiniCluster.scala integration test, some calls use unix based commands. However at the very least this PR should allow users to run a Livy server on a Windows machine, and with the changes it brings, it shouldn't be too hard to then resolve LIVY-611.
@vanzin Hi, could you assist with pushing it forward?

> Rethink about the way this ticket doing, I think current way may not be the best way.
> 
> 1. `jobId` may not exactly match the currently running jobs, there's no issue for beeline, but could be an issue for multi-thread usage. Currently when getting active jobs, there's no direct relation to jobId.
> 2. There's already a way to calculate job progress in ReplDriver for statement, we should extend the current way to also apply to job API.
> 3. Using LivyServer to store the session/job status may not be fault tolerant. It would better to extend the job API to get job progress synchronously.

Thanks for your reply, if I have understood your meaning correctly, actually I can use `jobId`(which is spark jobs' group id delivered by livy) in `handleProcessMessage` method of RSCDriver, then get related stages using this `jobId`, to handle these circumstances above. May this be a good way?

Hi @mgaido91 @jerryshao I had unify the configuration of ldap and the code has been commited. I wondered if we need to unify AUTH_TYPE and THRIFT_AUTHENTICATION in LivyConf.scala.
AUTH_TYPE is used in livy-server. Refer to the implementation of hadoop. Its value could be(lowercase): **kerberos\ldap\null\customType**
THRIFT_AUTHENTICATION is used in thrift-server. Refer to the implementation of hive. Its value could be(uppercase): **NOSASL\NONE\LDAP\KERBEROS\CUSTOM\PAM**
@yiheng test cases has been added.
@mgaido91 Could you help review this pr ?

I am not sure about the goal of this PR. May you please describe it? In general these types are supported, but they are serialized and treated as strings... I don't see that being changed: may you please explain which problem you had and why you decided to do this change?

@mgaido91  If `create table test(id decimal)`,  then `resultSet.getMetaData().getColumnTypeName(1) `will return `string`  rather than `decimal`. And I also test SparkThrift,  SparkThrift will return `decimal` , so it maybe necessary to return `decimal` instead of `string` in livy. The same to `timestamp `and `date`.

> > Rethink about the way this ticket doing, I think current way may not be the best way.
> > 
> > 1. `jobId` may not exactly match the currently running jobs, there's no issue for beeline, but could be an issue for multi-thread usage. Currently when getting active jobs, there's no direct relation to jobId.
> > 2. There's already a way to calculate job progress in ReplDriver for statement, we should extend the current way to also apply to job API.
> > 3. Using LivyServer to store the session/job status may not be fault tolerant. It would better to extend the job API to get job progress synchronously.
> 
> Thanks for your reply, if I have understood your meaning correctly, actually I can use `jobId`(which is spark jobs' group id delivered by livy) in `handleProcessMessage` method of RSCDriver, then get related stages using this `jobId`, to handle these circumstances above. May this be a good way?

@jerryshao After a deep dive into this implement, I find it is difficult to get job group id from RSCDriver, at first I thought `jobId` might be the spark job group id(because in JobWrapper class, it calls setting JobGroup with `jobId`), actually I'm wrong. Spark JobGroup is set as SqlJob's statementId, and if I want to get this statementId in JobWrapper or RscDriver, I must convert JobWrapper's Job to SqlJob, this needs SqlJob's definition, as SqlJob is in thriftserver module, importing its definition in rsc module may not be a good way. Could you please give me some advice?

@runzhiwang 
what I meant with

> This configuration flag maybe is not necessary. Even with this PR, getString() can still get the value of decimal, and the api is compatible.

was that you might have some code which does something like:

```
resultSet.getMetaData().getColumnTypeName(1) match {
  case "string" => resultSet.getString(1)
  ...
}
```

and it would be broken by this change. So I think we need the flag.

Please in the PR description, you should not just state *this is a problem*, you should say *this is a problem because ....*. Please also format code there. Moreover, please in the title write `[THRIFT]`, all uppercase instead of the current.
Thanks.
@captainzmc I don't agree with this unification. Please revert that. We might eventually try and do that in another PR focusing on that which also keeps compatibility. Thanks.

Hi @jahstreet ,We are running spark on kubernetes using the livy0.7 lincubator version.We are getting Message: Forbidden!Configured service account doesn't have access. Service account may have been revoked. pods is forbidden: User "system:serviceaccount:<namespace:serviceaccount" cannot list resource "pods" in API group "" at the cluster scope.We have seen that the api tries to find pods in all the cluster due to which we are seeing this error.Is there any way we can limit the pod or driver lookup limited to the namespace we have provided.
Could you please let us know how to overcome this error.

Service account may have been revoked. pods is forbidden: User "system:serviceaccount:<namespace:serviceaccount" cannot list resource "pods" in API group "" at the cluster scope.We have seen that the api tries to find pods in all the cluster due to which we are seeing this error.Is there any way we can limit the pod or driver lookup limited to the namespace we have provided.

We are running it as docker image ,that contains spark and livy deployed into k8s.

> Hi @jahstreet ,We are running spark on kubernetes using the livy0.7 lincubator version.We are getting Message: Forbidden!Configured service account doesn't have access. Hi, you need the appropriate RBAC configured for the Livy pod. You can refer the example [here](https://github.com/jahstreet/spark-on-kubernetes-helm/blob/master/charts/livy/templates/rbac.yaml). At present it is tended to be configured with the ClusterRole. To limit that a little patch is required. I see why you may need that to be supported.
Following the @mgaido91 review I will split this PR to multiple and will take into account your comment.

This patch seems to be a very useful feature for the community, has been open for over six months and splitting the patch unless really necessary is only going to delay this further.

> > > Rethink about the way this ticket doing, I think current way may not be the best way.
> > > 
> > > 1. `jobId` may not exactly match the currently running jobs, there's no issue for beeline, but could be an issue for multi-thread usage. Currently when getting active jobs, there's no direct relation to jobId.
> > > 2. There's already a way to calculate job progress in ReplDriver for statement, we should extend the current way to also apply to job API.
> > > 3. Using LivyServer to store the session/job status may not be fault tolerant. It would better to extend the job API to get job progress synchronously.

May this be a good way?

> @jerryshao After a deep dive into this implement, I find it is difficult to get job group id from RSCDriver, at first I thought `jobId` might be the spark job group id(because in JobWrapper class, it calls setting JobGroup with `jobId`), actually I'm wrong. Spark JobGroup is set as SqlJob's statementId, and if I want to get this statementId in JobWrapper or RscDriver, I must convert JobWrapper's Job to SqlJob, this needs SqlJob's definition, as SqlJob is in thriftserver module, importing its definition in rsc module may not be a good way. Could you please give me some advice?

@huianyi Reference thrift directly in the rsc will have circular references exception. We can use Java reflection in jobwrap.java, to avoid direct references. Such as:
`Field field = job.getClass().getDeclaredField("statementId");
  String statementId = field.get(job).toString();`

> @huianyi Reference thrift directly in the rsc will have circular references exception. We can use Java reflection in jobwrap.java, to avoid direct references. Such as:
> `Field field = job.getClass().getDeclaredField("statementId"); String statementId = field.get(job).toString();`

@captainzmc Yes, this is a way to solve the problem, but using reflection is a costly method, especially called multiple times, is there a more decent way to implement this?
Thanks for the review @ajbozarth. Do you know if https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LIVY-695 will be updated automatically? It is still open and the assignee isn't me.
thanks for pointing the out @peter-toth I'll fix that, the merge script has been failing the jira updates the last couple times I used it
Is the new implement reasonable? If yes, I'm gonna change other left problems.
Hope to find some time to test. Is this the way you use this feature ?

I would like to hear the comments from others. Here what I saw is that:

1. Each job will start a Timer, which is quite cost if the job is a very small job (metadata job).
2. The current way to get progress is using push based way, I was wondering if it is better to change to pull based way, so that we don't need to store such message in server side. Also we don't have to formalize the message in server side. For example, request: client -> server -> driver, and response: driver->server->client. Like what current repl did.

@mgaido91 can you please help to review this PR? Thanks.

thanks for pinging me @jerryshao. I share your concern on point 2. I think a good starting point would be checking how this is handled in Hive. @huianyi may you please check how Hive does this?

Apart from this, my main concern is: in many cases spark jobs are generated during the execution and not all of them are generated at the beginning of it. So these percentages cannot really be trusted IMHO. I wonder whether it is good to provide an information we know can be wrong or we best rather provide no information as it is now. Comments on this?
The second: https://github.com/apache/incubator-livy/pull/252

@mgaido91 Thanks for your reply, hive can be treated as hadoop client, it just call hadoop api to get job status (Class `Job` of hadoop code), therefore in hive, more specifically, hiveserver, it uses pull based way to get job process and then formalize the message, and put it in logs(like our operationMessage object), the client(beeline client) will pull these messages in a loop. Using pull based way in client side is a reasonable way, I'm gonna change this implement.

I don't think your main concern is a problem, on the one hand, we print detailed process messages of the job(like completed, active, etc), to some entent, these messages, which can be update in a certain intervel, can give end users enough information of their jobs, so at least they know how their jobs are running. On the other hand, I don't think there is a truly trusted percentage in a distribute system, hive may also show wrong percentages if a task is failed or hang there.

> 1. Each job will start a Timer, which is quite cost if the job is a very small job (metadata job).

@jerryshao we can not get detailed information of the job(such as if it is a metadata job) from livy side, so we might need to start a Timer for every job. also, spark use Timer to get job process(`ConsoleProgressBar`), maybe this cost is acceptable?

@jerryshao It's a bug.

Is this BigDecimal an exception to all other types, or we still have other types which have the similar behaviors? I think we should deliver a clear and consistent way to the users.

> @jerryshao It's a bug.

I don't agree on this. You are stating that the current behavior is wrong but I don't see a clear evidence of this. Please see https://github.com/apache/incubator-livy/pull/247#issuecomment-547007658
@mgaido91 @jerryshao could you please review?

@mgaido91 Hi, It's a bug because` resultSet.getBigDecimal` throw` java.sql.SQLException: Illegal conversion` in livy, which work normally in SparkThrift. If user use `getBigDecimal` and migrate from SparkThrift to Livy, it will throw exception.  And the updated PR description has more details about this.
